newsitem.title: CANADA: Goodale says more locomotives to move wheat.
newsitem.headline: Goodale says more locomotives to move wheat.

text.p: Canadian Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale told Parliament railway companies took steps to add more locomotives to move wheat to export ports.
"I'm glad to see the railways have taken some steps to bring more locomotive power to the situation," Goodale said to Parliament.
Goodale's spokesman, Vern Greenshields, in a phone interview from Ottawa with Reuters, played a tape recording of the remarks made in the House of Commons.
Forty-two vessels waited to load on Canada's Pacific coast on Monday as demurrage fines against the Canadian Wheat Board for delayed delivery exceeded C$15 million, the CWB said.
Shipment of more than 1.5 million tonnes of grain has been deferred so far since early January, the CWB said.
"I've had the opportunity to discuss the situation with some of the players on the shipping and grain side and plan to speak with more in the coming days," Goodale told Parliament.
Officials at Canadian National Railway Co and at Canadian Pacific unit CP Rail System were not immediately available for comment.
Saskatchewan Wheat Pool earlier Tuesday asked Goodale to call an emergency meeting to expedite grain shipment.
"This situation is critical," Goodale told Parliament.
The shipping delays forced the CWB to pass up wheat sales for February and March and may now threaten April delivery, CWB chief commissioner Lorne Hehn told Reuters earlier Tuesday.
